title: 103_s1208
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Independence Hall Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress finds that historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Congress Hall and Independence Hall, were cared for by local governments before the National Park Service took over preservation duties. However, financial constraints have hindered the government's ability to meet the capital needs of these sites. The Congress acknowledges financial constraints preventing the Federal Government from meeting the capital needs of historic sites in Philadelphia. Minting a United States coin can help commemorate these buildings and aid in funding their maintenance and preservation. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS.

The Secretary of the Treasury will issue up to 1,000,000 $1 coins made of 90% silver and 10% copper, weighing 26.73 grams with a diameter of 1.500 inches. The design will feature the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall, with inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". These coins will be legal tender.

SEC. 4. SOURCES OF BULLION.

Silver for the coins will be sourced from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. SEC. 4. SOURCES OF BULLION.

The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins only from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. 

SEC. 5. SELECTION OF DESIGN.

The design for the coins will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee.

SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF THE COINS.

The coins may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, minted at one facility for each quality, beginning 30 days after enactment for up to 1 year.

SEC. 7. SALE OF THE COINS. SEC. 7. SALE OF THE COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, a surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted. A surcharge of $7 per coin is required.

SEC. 8. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS.

Procurement regulations do not apply to goods or services needed for this Act. Compliance with equal employment opportunity laws is still required.

SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

The Secretary collects surcharges from coin sales, with 50% going to reduce the national debt and 50% to the Independence Hall Preservation Fund for park improvements. The Comptroller General can audit the Fund's expenditures. SEC. 11. NUMISMATIC PUBLIC ENTERPRISE FUND. The coins issued under this Act are subject to section 5134 of title 31, United States Code, relating to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 12. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the Government for issuing coins and require adequate security for payment.
